**Transcript**:
if you're an astronomy Enthusiast September end will be an exciting time that's because the biggest planet in the solar system will be at its closest to Earth in the last 59 years as it reaches its opposition from the Viewpoint of Earth's surface an opposition happens when an astronomical object rises in the east as the sun sets in the west placing the object and the sun on opposite sides of Earth according to NASA Jupiter's opposition occurs every 13 months making the planet appear larger and brighter than any other time of the year but that's not all Jupiter will also make its closest approach to Earth in the last 59 years this happens because Earth and Jupiter do not orbit the Sun in perfect circles meaning the planets will pass each other at different distances throughout the year Jupiter's closest approach to Earth rarely coincides with opposition which means this year's views will be extraordinary at its closest approach Jupiter would be approximately 367 million miles or 590 million kilometers from Earth about the same distance it was in 1963. the massive planet is about 600 million miles or 965 million kilometers away from Earth at its farthest point when a superior Planet reaches its opposition it rises in the east at Sunset reaches its highest point in the sky around midnight and sets in the west at dawn so Jupiter will shine brightly throughout the night well up in the night sky Jupiter is the brightest planet in the sky after Venus as seen from the Earth since Venus is only visible in the morning or evening Skies Jupiter will be the brightest Speck of light you'll see in the night sky the gas giant has 79 confirmed moons orbiting it and four of them can be easily seen through a modest telescope or even a pair of binoculars they're known as the Galilean moons named after Galileo Galilei who first discovered them in the 17th century with good binoculars the banding of Jupiter and three to four Galilean moons should be easily visible to see Jupiter's Great Red Spot and bans in more detail a four inch or larger telescope and some filters in the green to blue range would enhance the visibility of these features in binoculars or a telescope the Galilean satellites should appear as bright dots on either side of Jupiter during opposition an ideal viewing location will be at a high elevation in a dark and dry area The View should be great for a few days before and after September 26th so it would be best if you took advantage of good weather on either side of this date to take Insight if you look around in the night sky you should be able to see Saturn the ringed planet reached its opposition about a month ago and is slightly fainted Saturn Rises before Jupiter at dusk and reaches its highest point in the southern sky around midnight it's fairly bright and can be easily seen with the naked eye a telescopic view can reveal the beautiful rings of the planet as far as other planets concerned Mercury and Venus are still emerging from behind the Sun as a result they will remain hidden in its glare for the next few days Mars Rises around an hour before midnight and can be easily seen with unaided ice the red planet will reach its opposition on December 8 2022 hence as days pass by its distance from the earth will decrease and its apparent brightness will increase close to Mars lies Uranus at an apparent magnitude of 5.8 Neptune was at opposition on September 17th which means it's the best time of year to see the ice giant however Uranus and Neptune can only be seen through a telescope or a pair of binoculars the upcoming month is also going to be an exciting one for sky gazers October has as many as seven meteor showers in its store and the most significant one is the orionid meteor shower which Peaks around October 22nd besides that observers in parts of Africa Asia Europe and Greenland can witness a partial solar eclipse we'll cover the details in our monthly video of astronomical events if you enjoyed this video make sure to like it subscribe to our Channel and press the Bell icon so you don't miss any future astronomical events

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which is the biggest planet in our solar system?
Options: A. Neptune, B. Earth, C. Jupiter, D. Venus
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What is the approximate distance between Earth and Jupiter at its closest approach in the last 59 years? Options: A. 600 million miles, B. 367 million miles, C. 500 million miles, D. 1 billion miles Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the term for when an astronomical object rises in the east as the sun sets in the west, placing the object and the sun on opposite sides of Earth? Options: A. Opposition, B. Conjunction, C. Eclipse, D. Transit Correct Option: A
Question 3: What equipment would be necessary to observe Jupiter's Great Red Spot and bands in detail? Options: A. Binoculars and a star chart, B. A four-inch or larger telescope and some filters in the green to blue range, C. A pair of night vision goggles and a compass, D. A smartphone app and a tripod Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the meteor shower that peaks around October 22nd? Options: A. Perseid meteor shower, B. Orionid meteor shower, C. Geminid meteor shower, D. Leonid meteor shower Correct Option: B
Question 5: How often does Jupiter's opposition occur? Options: A. Every 6 months, B. Every 13 months, C. Every 2 years, D. Every 5 years Correct Option: B
Question 6: When is the best time to observe Neptune? Options: A. When it is at opposition, B. When it is in conjunction with the sun, C. When it is at its farthest point from Earth, D. When it is in retrograde motion Correct Option: A
Question 7: What equipment would be necessary to observe the Galilean moons of Jupiter? Options: A. A pair of binoculars or a modest telescope, B. A four-inch or larger telescope and some filters, C. A pair of night vision goggles and a compass, D. A smartphone app and a tripod Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the approximate distance between Earth and Jupiter at its farthest point? Options: A. 367 million miles, B. 600 million miles, C. 800 million miles, D. 965 million miles Correct Option: D
Question 9: Which planet reached its opposition about a month before Jupiter? Options: A. Saturn, B. Mars, C. Uranus, D. Neptune Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why is the upcoming opposition of Jupiter special? Options: A. Because it coincides with a total solar eclipse, B. Because it is the closest approach of Jupiter to Earth in the last 59 years, C. Because it is the farthest point of Jupiter from Earth, D. Because it is the brightest planet in the sky Correct Option: B

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: From the viewpoint of Earth’s surface, an opposition happens when:
Options: A. An astronomical object rises in the west as the Sun sets in the east, B. An astronomical object rises in the east as the Sun sets in the west, C. An astronomical object rises in the north as the Sun sets in the south, D. An astronomical object rises in the south as the Sun sets in the north
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate distance between Earth and Jupiter at its closest approach in the last 59 years? Options: A. 600 million miles, B. 367 million miles, C. 500 million miles, D. 1 billion miles Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the term for when an astronomical object rises in the east as the sun sets in the west, placing the object and the sun on opposite sides of Earth? Options: A. Opposition, B. Conjunction, C. Eclipse, D. Transit Correct Option: A
Question 3: What equipment would be necessary to observe Jupiter's Great Red Spot and bands in detail? Options: A. Binoculars and a star chart, B. A four-inch or larger telescope and some filters in the green to blue range, C. A pair of night vision goggles and a compass, D. A smartphone app and a tripod Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the meteor shower that peaks around October 22nd? Options: A. Perseid meteor shower, B. Orionid meteor shower, C. Geminid meteor shower, D. Leonid meteor shower Correct Option: B
Question 5: How often does Jupiter's opposition occur? Options: A. Every 6 months, B. Every 13 months, C. Every 2 years, D. Every 5 years Correct Option: B
Question 6: When is the best time to observe Neptune? Options: A. When it is at opposition, B. When it is in conjunction with the sun, C. When it is at its farthest point from Earth, D. When it is in retrograde motion Correct Option: A
Question 7: What equipment would be necessary to observe the Galilean moons of Jupiter? Options: A. A pair of binoculars or a modest telescope, B. A four-inch or larger telescope and some filters, C. A pair of night vision goggles and a compass, D. A smartphone app and a tripod Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the approximate distance between Earth and Jupiter at its farthest point? Options: A. 367 million miles, B. 600 million miles, C. 800 million miles, D. 965 million miles Correct Option: D
Question 9: Which planet reached its opposition about a month before Jupiter? Options: A. Saturn, B. Mars, C. Uranus, D. Neptune Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why is the upcoming opposition of Jupiter special? Options: A. Because it coincides with a total solar eclipse, B. Because it is the closest approach of Jupiter to Earth in the last 59 years, C. Because it is the farthest point of Jupiter from Earth, D. Because it is the brightest planet in the sky Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

opposition from the Viewpoint of Earth's surface an opposition happens when an astronomical object rises in the east as the sun sets in the west placing the object and the sun on opposite sides of Earth according to NASA Jupiter's opposition occurs every 13 months making the planet appear larger and brighter than any other time of the year but that's not all Jupiter will also make its closest approach to Earth in the last 59 years this happens because Earth and Jupiter do not orbit the Sun in perfect circles meaning the planets will pass each other at different distances throughout the year Jupiter's closest approach to Earth rarely coincides with opposition which means this year's views will be extraordinary at its closest approach Jupiter would be approximately 367 million miles or 590 million kilometers from Earth about the same distance it was in 1963. the massive planet is about 600 million miles or 965 million kilometers away from Earth at its farthest point when a superior Planet reaches its opposition it rises in the east at Sunset reaches its highest point in the sky around midnight and sets in the west at dawn so Jupiter will shine brightly throughout the night well up in the night sky Jupiter is the brightest planet in the sky after Venus as seen from the Earth since Venus is only visible in the morning or evening Skies Jupiter will be the brightest telescope the Galilean satellites should appear as bright dots on either side of Jupiter during opposition an ideal viewing location will be at a high elevation in a dark and dry area The View should be great for a few days before and after September 26th so it would be best if you took advantage of good weather on either side of this date to take Insight if you look around in the night sky you should be able to see Saturn the ringed planet reached its opposition about a month ago and is slightly fainted Saturn Rises before Jupiter at dusk and reaches its highest point in the southern sky around midnight it's fairly bright and can be easily seen with the naked eye a telescopic view can reveal the beautiful rings of the planet as far as other planets concerned Mercury and Venus are still emerging from behind the Sun as a result they will remain hidden in its glare for the next few days Mars Rises around an hour before midnight and can be easily seen with unaided ice the red planet will reach its opposition on December 8 2022 hence as days pass by its distance from the earth will decrease and its apparent brightness will increase close to Mars lies Uranus at an apparent magnitude of 5.8 Neptune was at opposition on September 17th which means it's the best time of year to see the ice giant however Uranus and Neptune can only be seen through a telescope or a pair of binoculars the upcoming month is also going to be an exciting one for sky gazers October has as many as seven meteor showers in its store and the most significant one is the orionid meteor shower which Peaks around October 22nd besides that observers in parts of Africa Asia Europe and Greenland can witness a partial solar eclipse we'll cover the details in our monthly video of astronomical events if you enjoyed this video make sure to like it subscribe to our Channel and press the Bell icon so you don't miss any future astronomical events

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a grocery store
in Brooklyn, New York, with sales per square foot 4 times 
as high as any other grocery store in the area. 10,000 people work there,
and it doesn’t have a CEO. This place is the Park Slope Food Co-op, and it’s one of 3 million cooperatives,
or co-ops for short, around the world. Co-ops are a big part 
of the global economy: they employ 280 million people—
10% of the world’s workforce and the equivalent of over $2 trillion
flow through their doors every year. How is it possible that a business 
with 10,000 workers doesn’t have a CEO? To answer that, we have to talk about what
a co-op is and why they were founded. Let’s rewind to 1844. A group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England came together to create 
and co-own a store. By buying in bulk directly from suppliers,
they could negotiate prices, which allowed all of them to buy stuff
they couldn't otherwise afford. They ran the store collectively
and democratically, which was remarkable at the time. The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers
wasn't the world's first co-op, but it was the first to publicize 
its principles— principles that guide co-ops to this day. Today, there are all kinds of co-ops: REI in the US and S-Group in Finland
are large consumer co-ops. Credit unions and mutual insurance
companies are financial sector co-ops. And when farmers or other producers come
together, that's a producer co-op. And then there are worker co-ops, like Mondragon in Spain or 
The Cheeseboard in Berkeley, California, which are founded to provide jobs
to people in the community. Some consumer co-ops, like Park Slope, require their members to work shifts 
in the store. In exchange for their work, members pay 
15 to 50% less for groceries, and they influence what products
are— or aren’t— sold there. Three crucial things to know about co-ops: first, all co-ops are jointly
owned by their members, whether those members are consumers,
producers, workers, or whoever. Unlike traditional companies, 
which can have outside shareholders, all owners of a co-op are also members. Second, co-ops are not founded
to maximize profit. Many do turn a significant profit, 
but that’s not their core mission. So evaluating a co-op purely 
by traditional business metrics ignores the most important reason
for their existence: how well do they serve their members? And third: co-ops are controlled
democratically by their members. But how do decisions get made? It varies. At a small worker co-op
like The Cheeseboard, day-to-day operational decisions
are just made by the workers. As co-ops get larger, they do institute
some form of leadership or management. Park Slope has a general manager 
who leads the 80 or so employees. And the largest network of worker 
and consumer co-ops in the world, Mondragon, has a president 
and managers who lead the roughly 30,000 worker-owners 
and 50,000 contract workers. But leadership roles in a co-op are very
different than in a traditional company. The leadership implements policies
that its members or worker-owners have agreed upon, by vote. And at Mondragon workers, 
can vote to fire the president. At a co-op, there’s no single person with overarching, top-down power 
over everyone else, like a CEO would have 
in a traditional company. Meanwhile, in both co-ops 
and traditional companies, major company-wide decisions
are made by voting. But who votes and how is wildly different. In a traditional company, voting rights 
usually come with shares of stock. The more shares you own, 
the more votes you have. Take Alphabet, 
the parent company of Google: there are thousands of shareholders, but the two founders control 51% 
of the votes and therefore the direction 
of the company. In a co-op, every member 
has the right to vote, and in most co-ops,
every member gets one vote. That difference results 
in radically different policies than you’d find at traditional companies. For example, Mondragon limits the salaries
of its management to about 6 times what the lowest paid 
worker makes. In Spain, CEOs of traditional companies 
make, on average, 143 times as much as a typical worker. At Park Slope, there’s a monthly 
general meeting, where any member can show up to vote, and a motion needs a
simple majority to pass. It then gets taken up by
the Board of directors, which is composed of co-op members,
for official approval. At The Cheeseboard, the worker-owners 
try to reach consensus on major decisions. This means that some decisions
can take a long time. For example, in the late 1970s, the workers debated whether to post
a sign outside declaring that The Cheeseboard was a collective
for one and a half years. But the extensive discussion, 
and disagreements, around that decision made it a solid one— The Cheeseboard still advertises
the fact that it’s a collective almost 50 years later. And that’s not all that’s
working well at co-ops. Studies in the UK show that co-op
start-ups are almost half as likely to close within five years
as traditional businesses. And in one study, 
researchers polled 600 workers at two in-home healthcare businesses: one was a worker co-op and the other
was a traditional company. The workers did similar work 
with similar salaries. The biggest difference? Co-op workers were 
about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Approximately how many cooperatives, or co-ops, are there around the world?
Options: A. 1 million, B. 2 million, C. 3 million, D. 4 million
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is unique about the Park Slope Food Co-op in Brooklyn, New York? Options: A. It has the highest sales per square foot in the world., B. It has a large number of employees but is owned by a single individual., C. It has 10,000 workers but no CEO., D. It is the largest co-op in the United States. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What motivated a group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England to create the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers in 1844? Options: A. To gain a competitive advantage over other businesses, B. To provide jobs to people in the community, C. To buy products at lower prices by buying in bulk, D. To create a new type of business model Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the primary goal of a co-op? Options: A. To maximize profit for shareholders, B. To provide jobs to people in the community, C. To serve the interests of a single owner, D. To serve the needs of its members Correct Option: D
Question 4: How do co-ops typically make decisions? Options: A. Through a top-down approach with a CEO making all the decisions, B. Through a democratic process with members voting on decisions, C. Through a consensus-based approach with all members agreeing on decisions, D. Through a combination of all the above Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main difference between how co-ops and traditional companies make decisions? Options: A. Co-ops make decisions based on profit, while traditional companies make decisions based on member needs., B. Co-ops make decisions through a democratic process, while traditional companies make decisions through a top-down approach., C. Co-ops make decisions based on member votes, while traditional companies make decisions based on shareholder votes., D. Co-ops make decisions quickly, while traditional companies take a long time to make decisions. Correct Option: C
Question 6: If you were to start a new business, what type of business model would you consider if you wanted to prioritize the needs of your employees and the community? Options: A. A traditional company with a CEO and outside shareholders, B. A non-profit organization with a board of directors, C. A co-op with member-owners and a democratic decision-making process, D. A sole proprietorship with a single owner Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the salary ratio between management and the lowest-paid worker at Mondragon? Options: A. 1:1, B. 6:1, C. 10:1, D. 20:1 Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a key advantage of co-ops compared to traditional businesses, according to the transcript? Options: A. Co-ops are more profitable than traditional businesses., B. Co-ops are more efficient than traditional businesses., C. Co-ops are more sustainable than traditional businesses., D. Co-ops have a lower failure rate than traditional businesses. Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the difference in job satisfaction between co-op workers and traditional company workers? Options: A. Co-op workers are 10% happier with their jobs., B. Co-op workers are 20% happier with their jobs., C. Co-op workers are 40% happier with their jobs., D. Co-op workers are 50% happier with their jobs. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What characteristic(s) distinguish co-ops from traditional companies? Options: A. Ownership structure, B. Decision-making process, C. Profit motive, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the topic of cooperatives.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the approximate number of cooperatives around the world. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs address this specific question.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is tangentially related to the topic, I would suggest Question 1. This question asks about the unique characteristic of the Park Slope Food Co-op, which is a specific example of a cooperative. While it doesn't address the global number of cooperatives, it does relate to the topic of cooperatives.

That being said, I must emphasize that none of the generated MCQs closely match the ground truth MCQ. If I had to provide an index, I would say that Question 1 is the closest, but it's still not a good match.

There's a grocery store
in Brooklyn, New York, with sales per square foot 4 times 
as high as any other grocery store in the area. 10,000 people work there,
and it doesn’t have a CEO. This place is the Park Slope Food Co-op, and it’s one of 3 million cooperatives,

a co-op is and why they were founded. Let’s rewind to 1844. A group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England came together to create 
and co-own a store. By buying in bulk directly from suppliers,

they couldn't otherwise afford. They ran the store collectively
and democratically, which was remarkable at the time. The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers

its principles— principles that guide co-ops to this day. Today, there are all kinds of co-ops: REI in the US and S-Group in Finland
are large consumer co-ops. Credit unions and mutual insurance

but that’s not their core mission. So evaluating a co-op purely

simple majority to pass. It then gets taken up by

try to reach consensus on major decisions. This means that some decisions

a sign outside declaring that The Cheeseboard was a collective
for one and a half years. But the extensive discussion, 
and disagreements, around that decision made it a solid one— The Cheeseboard still advertises
the fact that it’s a collective almost 50 years later. And that’s not all that’s

as traditional businesses. And in one study,

was a traditional company. The workers did similar work 
with similar salaries. The biggest difference? Co-op workers were 
about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers was the first
Options: A. Co-op, B. Co-op to publish their principles, C. Co-op of weavers, D. Publicly traded company
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is unique about the Park Slope Food Co-op in Brooklyn, New York? Options: A. It has the highest sales per square foot in the world., B. It has a large number of employees but is owned by a single individual., C. It has 10,000 workers but no CEO., D. It is the largest co-op in the United States. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What motivated a group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England to create the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers in 1844? Options: A. To gain a competitive advantage over other businesses, B. To provide jobs to people in the community, C. To buy products at lower prices by buying in bulk, D. To create a new type of business model Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the primary goal of a co-op? Options: A. To maximize profit for shareholders, B. To provide jobs to people in the community, C. To serve the interests of a single owner, D. To serve the needs of its members Correct Option: D
Question 4: How do co-ops typically make decisions? Options: A. Through a top-down approach with a CEO making all the decisions, B. Through a democratic process with members voting on decisions, C. Through a consensus-based approach with all members agreeing on decisions, D. Through a combination of all the above Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main difference between how co-ops and traditional companies make decisions? Options: A. Co-ops make decisions based on profit, while traditional companies make decisions based on member needs., B. Co-ops make decisions through a democratic process, while traditional companies make decisions through a top-down approach., C. Co-ops make decisions based on member votes, while traditional companies make decisions based on shareholder votes., D. Co-ops make decisions quickly, while traditional companies take a long time to make decisions. Correct Option: C
Question 6: If you were to start a new business, what type of business model would you consider if you wanted to prioritize the needs of your employees and the community? Options: A. A traditional company with a CEO and outside shareholders, B. A non-profit organization with a board of directors, C. A co-op with member-owners and a democratic decision-making process, D. A sole proprietorship with a single owner Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the salary ratio between management and the lowest-paid worker at Mondragon? Options: A. 1:1, B. 6:1, C. 10:1, D. 20:1 Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a key advantage of co-ops compared to traditional businesses, according to the transcript? Options: A. Co-ops are more profitable than traditional businesses., B. Co-ops are more efficient than traditional businesses., C. Co-ops are more sustainable than traditional businesses., D. Co-ops have a lower failure rate than traditional businesses. Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the difference in job satisfaction between co-op workers and traditional company workers? Options: A. Co-op workers are 10% happier with their jobs., B. Co-op workers are 20% happier with their jobs., C. Co-op workers are 40% happier with their jobs., D. Co-op workers are 50% happier with their jobs. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What characteristic(s) distinguish co-ops from traditional companies? Options: A. Ownership structure, B. Decision-making process, C. Profit motive, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a grocery store
in Brooklyn, New York, with sales per square foot 4 times 
as high as any other grocery store in the area. 10,000 people work there,
and it doesn’t have a CEO. This place is the Park Slope Food Co-op, and it’s one of 3 million cooperatives,
or co-ops for short, around the world. Co-ops are a big part 
of the global economy: they employ 280 million people—
10% of the world’s workforce and the equivalent of over $2 trillion
flow through their doors every year. How is it possible that a business 
with 10,000 workers doesn’t have a CEO? To answer that, we have to talk about what
a co-op is and why they were founded. Let’s rewind to 1844. A group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England came together to create 
and co-own a store. By buying in bulk directly from suppliers,
they could negotiate prices, which allowed all of them to buy stuff
they couldn't otherwise afford. They ran the store collectively
and democratically, which was remarkable at the time. The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers
wasn't the world's first co-op, but it was the first to publicize 
its principles— principles that guide co-ops to this day. Today, there are all kinds of co-ops: REI in the US and S-Group in Finland
are large consumer co-ops. Credit unions and mutual insurance
companies are financial sector co-ops. And when farmers or other producers come
together, that's a producer co-op. And then there are worker co-ops, like Mondragon in Spain or 
The Cheeseboard in Berkeley, California, which are founded to provide jobs
to people in the community. Some consumer co-ops, like Park Slope, require their members to work shifts 
in the store. In exchange for their work, members pay 
15 to 50% less for groceries, and they influence what products
are— or aren’t— sold there. Three crucial things to know about co-ops: first, all co-ops are jointly
owned by their members, whether those members are consumers,
producers, workers, or whoever. Unlike traditional companies, 
which can have outside shareholders, all owners of a co-op are also members. Second, co-ops are not founded
to maximize profit. Many do turn a significant profit, 
but that’s not their core mission. So evaluating a co-op purely 
by traditional business metrics ignores the most important reason
for their existence: how well do they serve their members? And third: co-ops are controlled
democratically by their members. But how do decisions get made? It varies. At a small worker co-op
like The Cheeseboard, day-to-day operational decisions
are just made by the workers. As co-ops get larger, they do institute
some form of leadership or management. Park Slope has a general manager 
who leads the 80 or so employees. And the largest network of worker 
and consumer co-ops in the world, Mondragon, has a president 
and managers who lead the roughly 30,000 worker-owners 
and 50,000 contract workers. But leadership roles in a co-op are very
different than in a traditional company. The leadership implements policies
that its members or worker-owners have agreed upon, by vote. And at Mondragon workers, 
can vote to fire the president. At a co-op, there’s no single person with overarching, top-down power 
over everyone else, like a CEO would have 
in a traditional company. Meanwhile, in both co-ops 
and traditional companies, major company-wide decisions
are made by voting. But who votes and how is wildly different. In a traditional company, voting rights 
usually come with shares of stock. The more shares you own, 
the more votes you have. Take Alphabet, 
the parent company of Google: there are thousands of shareholders, but the two founders control 51% 
of the votes and therefore the direction 
of the company. In a co-op, every member 
has the right to vote, and in most co-ops,
every member gets one vote. That difference results 
in radically different policies than you’d find at traditional companies. For example, Mondragon limits the salaries
of its management to about 6 times what the lowest paid 
worker makes. In Spain, CEOs of traditional companies 
make, on average, 143 times as much as a typical worker. At Park Slope, there’s a monthly 
general meeting, where any member can show up to vote, and a motion needs a
simple majority to pass. It then gets taken up by
the Board of directors, which is composed of co-op members,
for official approval. At The Cheeseboard, the worker-owners 
try to reach consensus on major decisions. This means that some decisions
can take a long time. For example, in the late 1970s, the workers debated whether to post
a sign outside declaring that The Cheeseboard was a collective
for one and a half years. But the extensive discussion, 
and disagreements, around that decision made it a solid one— The Cheeseboard still advertises
the fact that it’s a collective almost 50 years later. And that’s not all that’s
working well at co-ops. Studies in the UK show that co-op
start-ups are almost half as likely to close within five years
as traditional businesses. And in one study, 
researchers polled 600 workers at two in-home healthcare businesses: one was a worker co-op and the other
was a traditional company. The workers did similar work 
with similar salaries. The biggest difference? Co-op workers were 
about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What makes a co-op, a co-op?
Options: A. They are jointly owned by their members, B. They are NOT founded to maximize profits, C. They are controlled democratically, by their members, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is unique about the Park Slope Food Co-op in Brooklyn, New York? Options: A. It has the highest sales per square foot in the world., B. It has a large number of employees but is owned by a single individual., C. It has 10,000 workers but no CEO., D. It is the largest co-op in the United States. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What motivated a group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England to create the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers in 1844? Options: A. To gain a competitive advantage over other businesses, B. To provide jobs to people in the community, C. To buy products at lower prices by buying in bulk, D. Question 4: How do co-ops typically make decisions? Options: A. Through a top-down approach with a CEO making all the decisions, B. Through a democratic process with members voting on decisions, C. Through a consensus-based approach with all members agreeing on decisions, D. Through a combination of all the above Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main difference between how co-ops and traditional companies make decisions? Options: A. Co-ops make decisions based on profit, while traditional companies make decisions based on member needs., B. Co-ops make decisions through a democratic process, while traditional companies make decisions through a top-down approach., C. Co-ops make decisions based on member votes, while traditional companies make decisions based on shareholder votes., D. Co-ops make decisions quickly, while traditional companies take a long time to make decisions. Correct Option: C
Question 6: If you were to start a new business, what type of business model would you consider if you wanted to prioritize the needs of your employees and the community? Options: A. A traditional company with a CEO and outside shareholders, B. A non-profit organization with a board of directors, C. A co-op with member-owners and a democratic decision-making process, D. A sole proprietorship with a single owner Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the salary ratio between management and the lowest-paid worker at Mondragon? Options: A. 1:1, B. 6:1, C. 10:1, D. 20:1 Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a key advantage of co-ops compared to traditional businesses, according to the transcript? Options: A. Co-ops are more profitable than traditional businesses., B. Co-ops are more efficient than traditional businesses., C. Co-ops are more sustainable than traditional businesses., D. Co-ops have a lower failure rate than traditional businesses. Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the difference in job satisfaction between co-op workers and traditional company workers? Options: A. Co-op workers are 10% happier with their jobs., B. Co-op workers are 20% happier with their jobs., C. Co-op workers are 40% happier with their jobs., D. Co-op workers are 50% happier with their jobs. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What characteristic(s) distinguish co-ops from traditional companies? Options: A. Ownership structure, B. Decision-making process, C. Profit motive, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10. 

Question 10: What characteristic(s) distinguish co-ops from traditional companies? 
Options: A. Ownership structure, B. Decision-making process, C. Profit motive, D. All of the above 
Correct Option: D

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions aim to identify the key characteristics that define a co-op, and both have options that cover ownership structure, decision-making process, and profit motive. The correct option in both questions is "All of the above" or "D. All of the above", which indicates that co-ops are distinguished from traditional companies by their ownership structure, decision-making process, and profit motive.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10

about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who guides the direction of a traditional company? How do decisions get made?
Options: A. One person. One vote., B. The person or people with the most money decide, C. The person or people with the most amount of shares decide, D. Decision-makers are appointed by the board
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a grocery store
in Brooklyn, New York, with sales per square foot 4 times 
as high as any other grocery store in the area. 10,000 people work there,
and it doesn’t have a CEO. This place is the Park Slope Food Co-op, and it’s one of 3 million cooperatives,
or co-ops for short, around the world. Co-ops are a big part 
of the global economy: they employ 280 million people—
10% of the world’s workforce and the equivalent of over $2 trillion
flow through their doors every year. How is it possible that a business 
with 10,000 workers doesn’t have a CEO? To answer that, we have to talk about what
a co-op is and why they were founded. Let’s rewind to 1844. A group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England came together to create 
and co-own a store. By buying in bulk directly from suppliers,
they could negotiate prices, which allowed all of them to buy stuff
they couldn't otherwise afford. They ran the store collectively
and democratically, which was remarkable at the time. The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers
wasn't the world's first co-op, but it was the first to publicize 
its principles— principles that guide co-ops to this day. Today, there are all kinds of co-ops: REI in the US and S-Group in Finland
are large consumer co-ops. Credit unions and mutual insurance
companies are financial sector co-ops. And when farmers or other producers come
together, that's a producer co-op. And then there are worker co-ops, like Mondragon in Spain or 
The Cheeseboard in Berkeley, California, which are founded to provide jobs
to people in the community. Some consumer co-ops, like Park Slope, require their members to work shifts 
in the store. In exchange for their work, members pay 
15 to 50% less for groceries, and they influence what products
are— or aren’t— sold there. Three crucial things to know about co-ops: first, all co-ops are jointly
owned by their members, whether those members are consumers,
producers, workers, or whoever. Unlike traditional companies, 
which can have outside shareholders, all owners of a co-op are also members. Second, co-ops are not founded
to maximize profit. Many do turn a significant profit, 
but that’s not their core mission. So evaluating a co-op purely 
by traditional business metrics ignores the most important reason
for their existence: how well do they serve their members? And third: co-ops are controlled
democratically by their members. But how do decisions get made? It varies. At a small worker co-op
like The Cheeseboard, day-to-day operational decisions
are just made by the workers. As co-ops get larger, they do institute
some form of leadership or management. Park Slope has a general manager 
who leads the 80 or so employees. And the largest network of worker 
and consumer co-ops in the world, Mondragon, has a president 
and managers who lead the roughly 30,000 worker-owners 
and 50,000 contract workers. But leadership roles in a co-op are very
different than in a traditional company. The leadership implements policies
that its members or worker-owners have agreed upon, by vote. And at Mondragon workers, 
can vote to fire the president. At a co-op, there’s no single person with overarching, top-down power 
over everyone else, like a CEO would have 
in a traditional company. Meanwhile, in both co-ops 
and traditional companies, major company-wide decisions
are made by voting. But who votes and how is wildly different. In a traditional company, voting rights 
usually come with shares of stock. The more shares you own, 
the more votes you have. Take Alphabet, 
the parent company of Google: there are thousands of shareholders, but the two founders control 51% 
of the votes and therefore the direction 
of the company. In a co-op, every member 
has the right to vote, and in most co-ops,
every member gets one vote. That difference results 
in radically different policies than you’d find at traditional companies. For example, Mondragon limits the salaries
of its management to about 6 times what the lowest paid 
worker makes. In Spain, CEOs of traditional companies 
make, on average, 143 times as much as a typical worker. At Park Slope, there’s a monthly 
general meeting, where any member can show up to vote, and a motion needs a
simple majority to pass. It then gets taken up by
the Board of directors, which is composed of co-op members,
for official approval. At The Cheeseboard, the worker-owners

can take a long time. For example, in the late 1970s, the workers debated whether to post
a sign outside declaring that The Cheeseboard was a collective
for one and a half years. But the extensive discussion, 
and disagreements, around that decision made it a solid one— The Cheeseboard still advertises
the fact that it’s a collective almost 50 years later. And that’s not all that’s
working well at co-ops. Studies in the UK show that co-op
start-ups are almost half as likely to close within five years
as traditional businesses. And in one study, 
researchers polled 600 workers at two in-home healthcare businesses: one was a worker co-op and the other
was a traditional company. The workers did similar work 
with similar salaries. The biggest difference? Co-op workers were 
about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In a study done on businesses in the U.K, co-ops were ____ less likely to have closed down after 5 years.
Options: A. 20%, B. 30%, C. 40%, D. 50%
Correct Option: D

Question 1: What is unique about the Park Slope Food Co-op in Brooklyn, New York? Options: A. It has the highest sales per square foot in the world., B. Co-ops make decisions based on member votes, while traditional companies make decisions based on shareholder votes., D. Co-ops make decisions quickly, while traditional companies take a long time to make decisions. Correct Option: C
Question 6: If you were to start a new business, what type of business model would you consider if you wanted to prioritize the needs of your employees and the community? Options: A. A traditional company with a CEO and outside shareholders, B. A non-profit organization with a board of directors, C. A co-op with member-owners and a democratic decision-making process, D. A sole proprietorship with a single owner Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the salary ratio between management and the lowest-paid worker at Mondragon? Options: A. 1:1, B. 6:1, C. 10:1, D. 20:1 Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a key advantage of co-ops compared to traditional businesses, according to the transcript? Options: A. Co-ops are more profitable than traditional businesses., B. Co-ops are more efficient than traditional businesses., C. Co-ops are more sustainable than traditional businesses., D. Co-ops have a lower failure rate than traditional businesses. Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the difference in job satisfaction between co-op workers and traditional company workers? Options: A. Co-op workers are 10% happier with their jobs., B. Co-op workers are 20% happier with their jobs., C. Co-op workers are 40% happier with their jobs., D. Co-op workers are 50% happier with their jobs. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What characteristic(s) distinguish co-ops from traditional companies? Options: A. Ownership structure, B. Decision-making process, C. Profit motive, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 8: What is a key advantage of co-ops compared to traditional businesses, according to the transcript?**

Options: A. Co-ops are more profitable than traditional businesses., B. Co-ops are more efficient than traditional businesses., C. Co-ops are more sustainable than traditional businesses., D. Co-ops have a lower failure rate than traditional businesses.

Correct Option: D

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it asks about a specific advantage of co-ops compared to traditional businesses, which is related to the failure rate or closure rate of businesses. The ground truth MCQ asks about the likelihood of co-ops closing down after 5 years, while Question 8 asks about a key advantage of co-ops, which is their lower failure rate.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Pixar...the studio behind this,
and this, and this has mastered a sort of
photo-surrealistic style where there’s a sense of cartoony-ness but most things look and feel like they
could exist in the real world. Like these fibers on Mr. Incredible’s shirt. And this tree stump and grass from
this scene from Up. Or the glimmering, out-of-focus bokeh
behind Bo Peep. And it’s not just Pixar. These movies look so similar you can barely tell they’re from
different animation studios. But when you look at these movies it’s clear that something different
is happening. These lights don’t just illuminate;
they reveal a texture. This tree in the background 
isn’t out of focus it’s just got a simplified look. And this hair looks more like
brush strokes than human hair. These films are part of a new trend that’s steering animation away from 
replicating the real world and into somewhere new. Crafting beautiful animation in CG films requires a lot of dedicated artists
to perform specialized tasks: like rendering. Rendering is the process by which
a computer takes geometry, textures, lighting, camera inputs 
and does a bunch of math to apply all that information into
a final image. Like this one. Most render engines, like the one I’m using
here, are physically based which essentially means that it tries to replicate the real world physics
of light, shadow, reflection, and more. You can see this type of rendering
all over Pixar’s work even going back to their first movie. Rex looks like he could exist 
in the real world. Every meeting we would have, everybody
brought up like the Pixar look. The Pixar look was something that was very
high quality very successful at the box office so everybody kind of wanted the Pixar look. My name is Christos Obrenetov. Christos is the CEO of Lollipop Shaders a company that builds custom shaders
and plugins for 3D software. He’s worked on tons of films including "Life of Pi", "A Christmas Carol,"
and the upcoming "Across the Spider-Verse". But before all that he worked on a bunch of films that tried to
replicate that Pixar look. Because it was reliable, popular, and safe. Part of doing a feature film is, you know,
a lot of money and a lot of time. So they were kind of chasing that Pixar dream
of having that kind of a success. So to go and spend, you know, $100 million
or more... the investors and what not
are probably saying: "It's got to look like Pixar or Disney."
Right? And that was the case for a long time. Even when studios wanted to try
something different: Disney would come up and interview for a movie
that ended up being called "Bolt". They were showing us this really cool concept
art and they're like, "Oh, it's going to be super stylized." "It's going to look like sort of like 
the concept art." And it was very exciting. I was like, "Oh, this is great." And then when the movie 
did come out I mean, Bolt is fantastic, but they made it
very, you know, that same look. Movies like "Monster House" and "A Christmas
Carol" were intended to look stylized too but ultimately they settled back into
that tried-and-true physically based rendering look. There were glimmers of more stylized approaches
in short film tests and small sequences like in Disney’s Moana. But this stylized sequence
is only about 30 seconds out of the hour and 43 minute-long film. A lot of studios have been playing with
this for a long time. But to take that risk to do a full feature film that's
very stylized in 3D I think people were scared. And that fear kept studios from making
bold choices. Until 2017 when the trailer for
"Into the Spider-Verse" dropped. It had simplified graphic bursts that felt
like comic book panels. There was no motion blur or depth of field and everything, from the characters to the
environments, was full of texture. According to one of the animation supervisors
for the project after a year and a half of work the studio was still nervous that people were
going to hate the visuals. Because they felt like they were taking too
many risks. Instead of leaning into the safe, physically
based, rendering look "Into the Spider-Verse" chose to use 
non-photorealistic rendering. To pull this off, they essentially had to
break their physically-based renderer. Instead of inputting data from lights, 
camera, and materials and receiving a realistic looking render they combined all that data with custom
data passes that tweaked things like the focus plane or the way the light worked
in an image. This combo allowed the renderer 
to produce stylized results. For example, in "Into the Spider-verse",
out of focus elements aren’t blurry. Instead, the colors split as if the screen printing on an actual 
comic book was done poorly. Lighting and shadow were approached
in new ways too. Light often reveals halftone dots. And shadows create sketchy hatch marks. But there’s more than just shading magic
happening here. Non-photorealistic renderings often use linework 2D elements like speed lines and doubles and variable frame rates to pull these frames
further away from reality and often, closer to the concept art. Just two months after its release "Into the Spider-Verse" became the highest grossing
film Sony Pictures animation had ever made. It doesn’t hold a candle to Pixar
in terms of lifetime gross: "Incredibles 2" sits at the number one spot while Spider-verse doesn’t even crack
the top 50. But, much like Pixar did in the first wave
of CG animated features "Into the Spider-Verse" redefined
the visual goals for animation studios. 2021’s "The Mitchells vs the Machines" and
2022’s "Puss in Boots" take non-photorealistic rendering in a different,
more painterly direction where out-of-focus objects 
become simplified shapes emulating the way that artists may use 
simplified marks in backgrounds "In the Mitchells vs the Machines", shadows
create different marker textures. Puss in Boots’ simplified 2D cutaways mimic
the graphic bursts of Into the Spider-verse. People were like, "Oh, this is looks really
good and it's different". So now, all future projects at studios from
DreamWorks and Imageworks and Pixar— they're looking at the next whatever, five
years or whatnot. It's all like very stylized. And that’s really exciting because non-photorealism allows animated movies
to take advantage of the things that make them special. They can be anything the imagination allows.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What style has Pixar mastered?
Options: A. Photo-impressionist, B. Photo-surrealistic, C. Photo-realistic, D. Photo-synthetic
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Which animation studio is known for its photo-surrealistic style, where most things look and feel like they could exist in the real world? Options: A. Pixar, B. Disney, C. DreamWorks, D. Sony Pictures Animation Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is rendering in the context of computer-generated (CG) films? Options: A. The process of creating concept art, B. The process by which a computer takes geometry, textures, lighting, and camera inputs to produce a final image, C. The process of adding special effects to a film, D. The process of editing a film's soundtrack Correct Option: B
Question 3: What type of rendering is commonly used in most render engines, including the one mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. Non-photorealistic rendering, B. Physically based rendering, C. Stylized rendering, D. Cartoonish rendering Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to Christos Obrenetov, what was the primary reason behind many studios trying to replicate the "Pixar look" in their films? Options: A. To create a new and innovative style, B. To minimize financial risk by using a reliable and popular style, C. To showcase their technical capabilities, D. To appeal to a specific target audience Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the film "Into the Spider-Verse" in terms of animation style? Options: A. It was the first film to use physically based rendering, B. It was a feature-length film that successfully used non-photorealistic rendering, C. It was the first film to combine 2D and 3D animation, D. It was the first film to use motion capture technology Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the animation team behind "Into the Spider-Verse" achieve the film's stylized look? Options: A. By using a new rendering engine, B. By combining data from lights, camera, and materials with custom data passes, C. By adding special effects in post-production, D. By using traditional animation techniques Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is one of the characteristics of non-photorealistic rendering, as seen in "Into the Spider-Verse"? Options: A. Out-of-focus elements are blurry, B. Out-of-focus elements are simplified shapes, C. Out-of-focus elements have colors that split like screen printing, D. Out-of-focus elements are removed from the scene Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the film "The Mitchells vs the Machines" use non-photorealistic rendering, according to the transcript? Options: A. It uses a more realistic approach to lighting and shadows, B. It uses a more painterly direction, with out-of-focus objects becoming simplified shapes, C. It uses a more cartoonish approach to character design, D. It uses a more stylized approach to sound design Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the potential benefit of non-photorealistic rendering in animated films, according to the transcript? Options: A. It allows for more realistic environments and characters, B. It enables more stylized and imaginative storytelling, C. It reduces rendering times, D. It improves lighting and shadows Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to Christos Obrenetov, what is the current trend in animation studios, in terms of visual style? Options: A. A return to traditional animation techniques, B. A focus on realistic, physically based rendering, C. A shift towards more stylized, non-photorealistic rendering, D. An emphasis on motion capture technology Correct Option: C

and this, and this has mastered a sort of
photo-surrealistic style where there’s a sense of cartoony-ness but most things look and feel like they
could exist in the real world. Like these fibers on Mr. Incredible’s shirt. And this tree stump and grass from

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Non-photorealism allows animated movies to take advantage of what makes them special. Which is:
Options: A. They can be anything the imagination allows, B. They can have better special effects, C. They can have a larger cast of actors, D. They don't have to rely on the accurate history of the world
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Which animation studio is known for its photo-surrealistic style, where most things look and feel like they could exist in the real world? Options: A. Pixar, B. Disney, C. DreamWorks, D. Sony Pictures Animation Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is rendering in the context of computer-generated (CG) films? Options: A. The process of creating concept art, B. The process of editing a film's soundtrack Correct Option: B

It was the first film to use motion capture technology Correct Option: B

By combining data from lights, camera, and materials with custom data passes, C. By adding special effects in post-production, D. By using traditional animation techniques Correct Option: B

Out-of-focus elements are simplified shapes, C. Out-of-focus elements have colors that split like screen printing, D. Out-of-focus elements are removed from the scene Correct Option: C

It uses a more painterly direction, with out-of-focus objects becoming simplified shapes, C. It uses a more cartoonish approach to character design, D. It uses a more stylized approach to sound design Correct Option: B

A focus on realistic, physically based rendering, C. A shift towards more stylized, non-photorealistic rendering, D. An emphasis on motion capture technology Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On a daily basis, you spend
between a third and half your waking hours daydreaming. That may sound like a huge waste of time, but scientists think it must have 
some purpose, or humans wouldn’t have evolved
to do so much of it. So to figure out what's going on here, let’s take a closer look 
at the mind-wanderer in chief: the bored teenager. Wouldn’t it be cool to discover something,
anything. Like even this plant. Just to be one of those explorers who 
sails around drawing stuff for years on end 
and everyone thinks they’re a genius. But does anyone even do that anymore? Is there anything left to discover? And would I be tough enough to deal 
with the dysentery or scurvy or piranhas or whatever? I barely have the endurance
to make it through track practice... but I will. Any day now, I’ll have the
discipline to show up before sunrise and practice. I’ll win all my races. Winning will become so easy,
I’ll pick up other events just for fun. And once I'm in the Olympics, they’ll have no choice 
but to crown me team captain, which I will graciously accept. And will I be nasty to the teammate
who yelled at me? No. I’ll just calmly say, 
“hope you’re in a better mood.” Okay. Yours and other people's daydreams
might sound or feel something like that. Let's see what was going on. To see what parts of the brain are active when you’re doing a task, or thinking,
or daydreaming, scientists use brain imaging techniques 
that show increased blood flow and energy 
expenditure in those areas. These brain areas are active, working together and communicating
with each other. Taken together, they're called
the executive network. When your mind starts to wander, a different set of brain areas
becomes active. These areas make up the
default mode network. The name default mode makes it sound
like nothing is going on. And in fact, for many years, scientists associated this pattern
of activity with rest. But a closer look reveals that these
are the brain areas involved when we revisit a memory, when we think
about our plans and hopes, and yes, when our minds are wandering
off on a wild daydream. The mind can wander to unproductive
or distressing places and brood over negative past events,
like an argument. It can also wander to neutral,
everyday matters, like planning out the rest
of one's afternoon. But where mind-wandering 
really gets interesting is when it crosses into the realm 
of free-moving associative thought that you aren’t consciously directing. This kind of mind-wandering is associated 
with increases in both ideas and positive emotions, and the evidence suggests that daydreaming
can help people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate
relationships and social situations. Scientists think there may be 
two essential parts to this process: a generative phase of free-flowing ideas
and spontaneous thoughts, courtesy of the default mode network, followed by a process of selecting, 
developing, and pursuing the best ideas from that generative burst, driven by logical thinking 
thanks to the executive network. A host of imaging studies suggest that
these two networks working in sync is a crucial condition 
for creative thinking. Taken together, the evidence clearly
suggests the logical realm of the executive network and the imaginative realm 
of the default mode network are closely related. And as you can see, the executive network
is still playing a role when the default mode network is
doing its thing during daydreaming. In teenagers, the prefrontal cortex and other areas
involved in executive function are still developing, but teens are perfectly capable of 
thinking through their problems and goals, especially when given space to do so
on their own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Between what percentage do humans spend their days daydreaming?
Options: A. Between one quarter and one third, B. Between one third and one half, C. Between one half and three quarters, D. Almost all the time
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of waking hours do humans typically spend daydreaming? Options: A. Between 10% and 20%, B. Between a third and half, C. Between 60% and 70%, D. More than 80% Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary function of the default mode network in the brain, according to scientists? Options: A. To control logical thinking and problem-solving, B. To facilitate rest and relaxation, C. To revisit memories, think about plans and hopes, and enable mind-wandering, D. To regulate emotions and social behavior Correct Option: C
Question 3: A student is having trouble focusing on their homework and keeps thinking about their plans for the weekend. Which brain network is most likely active in this scenario? Options: A. Executive network, B. Default mode network, C. Sensory network, D. Motor network Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the proposed two-part process involved in creative thinking, according to scientists? Options: A. Generative phase followed by a critical thinking phase, B. Logical thinking phase followed by a creative brainstorming phase, C. Generative phase of free-flowing ideas followed by a process of selecting and developing the best ideas, D. Analytical phase followed by a problem-solving phase Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the name of the brain network responsible for logical thinking and problem-solving? Options: A. Default mode network, B. Executive network, C. Sensory network, D. Motor network Correct Option: B
Question 6: A teenager is trying to come up with ideas for a creative writing project. What would be the most effective way for them to generate ideas, based on the transcript? Options: A. By focusing intensely on the task and trying to come up with ideas through logical thinking, B. By taking a break and letting their mind wander, allowing the default mode network to generate ideas, C. By brainstorming with a group of friends and trying to come up with ideas through discussion, D. By reading books and articles on the topic and trying to come up with ideas through research Correct Option: B
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between the executive network and the default mode network? Options: A. They are two separate networks that work independently of each other, B. They are two networks that work together in sync to facilitate creative thinking, C. The executive network is responsible for controlling the default mode network, D. The default mode network is responsible for controlling the executive network Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a benefit of daydreaming, according to the transcript? Options: A. It helps people focus and concentrate on tasks, B. It helps people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate relationships and social situations, C. It helps people relax and reduce stress, D. It has no benefits and is a waste of time Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is still developing in teenagers? Options: A. The default mode network, B. The executive network, C. The prefrontal cortex and other areas involved in executive function, D. The sensory network Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a result of the default mode network and executive network working together in sync, according to the transcript? Options: A. Increased focus and concentration, B. Improved memory and recall, C. Increased creativity and idea generation, D. Better emotional regulation Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Transcript**:
On a daily basis, you spend
between a third and half your waking hours daydreaming. That may sound like a huge waste of time, but scientists think it must have 
some purpose, or humans wouldn’t have evolved
to do so much of it. So to figure out what's going on here, let’s take a closer look 
at the mind-wanderer in chief: the bored teenager. Wouldn’t it be cool to discover something,
anything. Like even this plant. Just to be one of those explorers who 
sails around drawing stuff for years on end 
and everyone thinks they’re a genius. But does anyone even do that anymore? Is there anything left to discover? And would I be tough enough to deal 
with the dysentery or scurvy or piranhas or whatever? I barely have the endurance
to make it through track practice... but I will. Any day now, I’ll have the
discipline to show up before sunrise and practice. I’ll win all my races. Winning will become so easy,
I’ll pick up other events just for fun. And once I'm in the Olympics, they’ll have no choice 
but to crown me team captain, which I will graciously accept. And will I be nasty to the teammate
who yelled at me? No. I’ll just calmly say, 
“hope you’re in a better mood.” Okay. Yours and other people's daydreams
might sound or feel something like that. Let's see what was going on. To see what parts of the brain are active when you’re doing a task, or thinking,
or daydreaming, scientists use brain imaging techniques 
that show increased blood flow and energy 
expenditure in those areas. These brain areas are active, working together and communicating
with each other. Taken together, they're called
the executive network. When your mind starts to wander, a different set of brain areas
becomes active. These areas make up the
default mode network. The name default mode makes it sound
like nothing is going on. And in fact, for many years, scientists associated this pattern
of activity with rest. But a closer look reveals that these
are the brain areas involved when we revisit a memory, when we think
about our plans and hopes, and yes, when our minds are wandering
off on a wild daydream. The mind can wander to unproductive
or distressing places and brood over negative past events,
like an argument. It can also wander to neutral,
everyday matters, like planning out the rest
of one's afternoon. But where mind-wandering 
really gets interesting is when it crosses into the realm 
of free-moving associative thought that you aren’t consciously directing. This kind of mind-wandering is associated 
with increases in both ideas and positive emotions, and the evidence suggests that daydreaming
can help people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate
relationships and social situations. Scientists think there may be 
two essential parts to this process: a generative phase of free-flowing ideas
and spontaneous thoughts, courtesy of the default mode network, followed by a process of selecting, 
developing, and pursuing the best ideas from that generative burst, driven by logical thinking 
thanks to the executive network. A host of imaging studies suggest that
these two networks working in sync is a crucial condition 
for creative thinking. Taken together, the evidence clearly
suggests the logical realm of the executive network and the imaginative realm 
of the default mode network are closely related. And as you can see, the executive network
is still playing a role when the default mode network is
doing its thing during daydreaming. In teenagers, the prefrontal cortex and other areas
involved in executive function are still developing, but teens are perfectly capable of 
thinking through their problems and goals, especially when given space to do so
on their own.

of free-moving associative thought that you aren’t consciously directing. This kind of mind-wandering is associated 
with increases in both ideas and positive emotions, and the evidence suggests that daydreaming
can help people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate
relationships and social situations. Scientists think there may be 
two essential parts to this process: a generative phase of free-flowing ideas
and spontaneous thoughts, courtesy of the default mode network, followed by a process of selecting, 
developing, and pursuing the best ideas from that generative burst, driven by logical thinking 
thanks to the executive network. A host of imaging studies suggest that
these two networks working in sync is a crucial condition 
for creative thinking. Taken together, the evidence clearly
suggests the logical realm of the executive network and the imaginative realm 
of the default mode network are closely related. And as you can see, the executive network
is still playing a role when the default mode network is
doing its thing during daydreaming. In teenagers, the prefrontal cortex and other areas
involved in executive function are still developing, but teens are perfectly capable of 
thinking through their problems and goals, especially when given space to do so
on their own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If the default mode network in your brain is active, you are most likely:
Options: A. Planning a friend's birthday party, B. Putting together a puzzle, C. Taking notes while studying, D. Imagining what your future might be like
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of waking hours do humans typically spend daydreaming? Options: A. Between 10% and 20%, B. Between a third and half, C. Between 60% and 70%, D. More than 80% Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary function of the default mode network in the brain, according to scientists? Options: A. To control logical thinking and problem-solving, B. To facilitate rest and relaxation, C. To revisit memories, think about plans and hopes, and enable mind-wandering, D. To regulate emotions and social behavior Correct Option: C

Logical thinking phase followed by a creative brainstorming phase, C. Generative phase of free-flowing ideas followed by a process of selecting and developing the best ideas, D. Analytical phase followed by a problem-solving phase Correct Option: C

By focusing intensely on the task and trying to come up with ideas through logical thinking, B. By taking a break and letting their mind wander, allowing the default mode network to generate ideas, C. By brainstorming with a group of friends and trying to come up with ideas through discussion, D. The executive network is responsible for controlling the default mode network, D. The default mode network is responsible for controlling the executive network Correct Option: B

It helps people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate relationships and social situations, C. It helps people relax and reduce stress, D. It has no benefits and is a waste of time Correct Option: B

Improved memory and recall, C. Increased creativity and idea generation, D. Better emotional regulation Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On a daily basis, you spend
between a third and half your waking hours daydreaming. That may sound like a huge waste of time, but scientists think it must have 
some purpose, or humans wouldn’t have evolved
to do so much of it. So to figure out what's going on here, let’s take a closer look 
at the mind-wanderer in chief: the bored teenager. Wouldn’t it be cool to discover something,
anything. Like even this plant. Just to be one of those explorers who 
sails around drawing stuff for years on end 
and everyone thinks they’re a genius. But does anyone even do that anymore? Is there anything left to discover? And would I be tough enough to deal 
with the dysentery or scurvy or piranhas or whatever? I barely have the endurance
to make it through track practice... but I will. Any day now, I’ll have the
discipline to show up before sunrise and practice. I’ll win all my races. Winning will become so easy,
I’ll pick up other events just for fun. And once I'm in the Olympics, they’ll have no choice 
but to crown me team captain, which I will graciously accept. And will I be nasty to the teammate
who yelled at me? No. I’ll just calmly say, 
“hope you’re in a better mood.” Okay. Yours and other people's daydreams
might sound or feel something like that. Let's see what was going on. To see what parts of the brain are active when you’re doing a task, or thinking,
or daydreaming, scientists use brain imaging techniques 
that show increased blood flow and energy 
expenditure in those areas. These brain areas are active, working together and communicating
with each other. Taken together, they're called
the executive network. When your mind starts to wander, a different set of brain areas
becomes active. These areas make up the
default mode network. The name default mode makes it sound
like nothing is going on. And in fact, for many years, scientists associated this pattern
of activity with rest. But a closer look reveals that these
are the brain areas involved when we revisit a memory, when we think
about our plans and hopes, and yes, when our minds are wandering
off on a wild daydream. The mind can wander to unproductive
or distressing places and brood over negative past events,
like an argument. It can also wander to neutral,
everyday matters, like planning out the rest
of one's afternoon. But where mind-wandering 
really gets interesting is when it crosses into the realm 
of free-moving associative thought that you aren’t consciously directing. This kind of mind-wandering is associated 
with increases in both ideas and positive emotions, and the evidence suggests that daydreaming
can help people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate
relationships and social situations. Scientists think there may be 
two essential parts to this process: a generative phase of free-flowing ideas
and spontaneous thoughts, courtesy of the default mode network, followed by a process of selecting, 
developing, and pursuing the best ideas from that generative burst, driven by logical thinking 
thanks to the executive network. A host of imaging studies suggest that
these two networks working in sync is a crucial condition 
for creative thinking. Taken together, the evidence clearly
suggests the logical realm of the executive network and the imaginative realm 
of the default mode network are closely related. And as you can see, the executive network
is still playing a role when the default mode network is
doing its thing during daydreaming. In teenagers, the prefrontal cortex and other areas
involved in executive function are still developing, but teens are perfectly capable of 
thinking through their problems and goals, especially when given space to do so
on their own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does the evidence suggest about the relationship between the more logical side of our brain (the executive network) and the more creative side of our brain (the default mode network)?
Options: A. They are totally separate from one another, B. They cannot operate simultaneously, C. That they can be related to one another and active at the same time, D. That they often come into conflict with one another
Correct Option: C
